  2. The table exists, but the table name is different. Check if the table name in the SQL query matches the actual table name in the database.

  3. The database connection is not established correctly. Make sure that the connection parameters (host, username, password, database name) are correct and the connection is established before running the query.

To fix this issue, you can do the following:

The error message "Unknown table 'foodclover.orders'" indicates that the SQL query is trying to access a table that does not exist or is misspelled. The error occurs on line 36 of the PHP code.

You need to ensure that the table name in the query is correct and that it exists in the database. Double-check the spelling and ensure that the table exists in the database.

If the table exists and the query is still failing, check if the table is in the same database that you are connecting to. If it is in a different database, you may need to modify your SQL query to reference the correct database.

You can also use the mysqli_error() function to get more details about the error. You can add the following code after the query to see the error message:

php
if (!$result) {
    die(mysqli_error($conn));
}

This will output the error message if the query fails, which can help you diagnose the problem.

  3. Check that the orders table has data and that there are matching records in the customers, guests, and dishes tables for the specified customer_id or guest_id. You can do this by running separate SQL queries to retrieve data from these tables.

  4. Check that the column names in your SQL query match the actual column names in your database tables. Remember that column names are case sensitive in SQL.

  5. Try modifying your SQL query to use explicit table names rather than implicit table names. For example, instead of INNER JOIN customers c ON orders.customer_id = c.customer_id, use INNER JOIN customersONorders.customer_id=customers.customer_id``.

  6. Try modifying your SQL query to use single quotes around the $where_condition variable. For example, instead of WHERE $where_condition, use WHERE '$where_condition'.

  7. Make sure that the $quantity and $price variables are set to the correct values by adding a print_r($row); statement inside the while loop to see the entire row of data that is being fetched from the database.

Hopefully, one of these solutions will help you identify and fix the issue with your SQL query.

Based on the code you provided, it seems that the issue is with the SQL query. The $where_condition variable is only defined when either $_GET['customer_id'] or $_GET['guest_id'] is set, and it is used in the WHERE clause of the query.

However, if neither $_GET['customer_id'] nor $_GET['guest_id'] is set, the $where_condition variable is undefined and therefore the query will not return any results. This might be why the variables are not being populated.

To fix this issue, you can add an else statement after the if block to define $where_condition in case neither $_GET['customer_id'] nor $_GET['guest_id'] is set. Here's an example:

php
if(isset($_GET['customer_id'])) {
  $customer_id = $_GET['customer_id'];
  $where_condition = "orders.customer_id = $customer_id";
} elseif(isset($_GET['guest_id'])) {
  $guest_id = $_GET['guest_id'];
  $where_condition = "orders.guest_id = $guest_id";
} else {
  $where_condition = "1"; // return all records
}

// ...

$sql = "SELECT orders.*, orders.dish_id, orders.quantity, orders.created_at, dishes.dish_name, dishes.price, orders.customer_id, orders.guest_id, orders.reservation_id, orders.order_status, orders.order_id,  guests.name, guests.email, guests.phone_number, customers.full_name, customers.email, customers.phone
FROM orders
INNER JOIN customers ON orders.customer_id = customers.customer_id
INNER JOIN guests ON guests.guest_id = orders.guest_id
INNER JOIN dishes  ON orders.dish_id = dishes.dish_id
WHERE $where_condition";

$result = $conn->query($sql);

This will set $where_condition to 1 if neither $_GET['customer_id'] nor $_GET['guest_id'] is set, which will return all records.

Based on the provided code, it seems that the variable names are only assigned values inside the while loop that fetches data from the database. This means that the variables are being overwritten for each row of data that is fetched, so only the values for the last row of data will be stored in the variables.

If you want to store all the data from the table, you can create arrays to store each column's data instead of individual variables. For example, you can create an array to store all the dish IDs, another array to store all the quantities, etc. Then you can use these arrays to generate the PDF.

Here's an example of how you can modify your code to store the data in arrays:

scss
$dish_ids = array();
$quantities = array();
$prices = array();
$customer_names = array();
$customer_ids = array();
$guest_ids = array();
$reservation_ids = array();
$reservation_dates = array();
$order_ids = array();
$names = array();
$emails = array();
$customer_emails = array();
$customer_phones = array();

if ($result->num_rows > 0) {
  // output data of each row
  while($row = $result->fetch_assoc()) {

    $dish_ids[] = $row["dish_id"];
    $quantities[] = $row["quantity"];
    $prices[] = $row["price"];
    $customer_names[] = $row["full_name"];
    $customer_ids[] = $row["customer_id"];
    $guest_ids[] = $row["guest_id"];
    $reservation_ids[] = $row["reservation_id"];
    $reservation_dates[] = $row["created_at"];
    $order_ids[] = $row["order_id"];
    $names[] = $row["name"];
    $emails[] = $row["email"];
    $customer_emails[] = $row["email"];
    $customer_phones[] = $row["phone"];
  }
}

With this modification, the data from the database should be stored in arrays, which can then be used to generate the PDF.

can you give me sql code for the delivery table where if the delivery_status changes from pending to completed is it should add the quanitity in the delivery table to the inventory_stock column in customers table and this code should continour update even after the sql code is inserted is should keep checking
1 / 1

Certainly! Here's an example of SQL code that you can use to accomplish this:

sql
CREATE TRIGGER update_inventory
AFTER UPDATE ON delivery
FOR EACH ROW
BEGIN
    IF OLD.delivery_status = 'pending' AND NEW.delivery_status = 'completed' THEN
        UPDATE customers
        SET inventory_stock = inventory_stock + NEW.quantity
        WHERE customer_id = NEW.customer_id;
    END IF;
END;

This code creates a trigger called update_inventory that fires after an update is made to the delivery table. The trigger checks if the delivery status has changed from "pending" to "completed". If it has, then the trigger updates the inventory_stock column in the customers table for the customer associated with the updated delivery, adding the quantity from the updated delivery.

The trigger is set to fire FOR EACH ROW, meaning that it will run once for each row that is updated in the delivery table.

Once this trigger is created, it will continue to run automatically whenever an update is made to the delivery table that meets the specified criteria.

If you don't have the customer_id column in the delivery table, you can use a join to get the customer_id from the customers table using the customer_name column, assuming it is present in both tables. Here is an example code:

sql
DELIMITER $$
CREATE TRIGGER update_inventory
AFTER UPDATE ON delivery
FOR EACH ROW
BEGIN
    IF OLD.delivery_status = 'pending' AND NEW.delivery_status = 'completed' THEN
        UPDATE customers c
        JOIN delivery d ON c.customer_name = d.customer_name
        SET c.inventory_stock = c.inventory_stock + NEW.quantity
        WHERE d.delivery_id = NEW.delivery_id;
    END IF;
END$$
DELIMITER ;

In this example, we assume that both the delivery and customers tables have a customer_name column, and the delivery table has a delivery_id column. The trigger updates the inventory_stock column in the customers table with the new quantity value for the corresponding customer.

can you give me sql code for the delivery table where if the delivery_status changes from pending to completed is it should add the quanitity in the delivery table to the inventory_stock column in ingredients table and this code should continour update even after the sql code is inserted is should keep checking
1 / 1

Sure, here's the SQL code for creating a trigger on the delivery table that updates the inventory_stock column in the ingredients table when a delivery's status changes from pending to completed:

sql
DELIMITER $$
CREATE TRIGGER update_inventory
AFTER UPDATE ON delivery
FOR EACH ROW
BEGIN
    IF OLD.delivery_status = 'pending' AND NEW.delivery_status = 'completed' THEN
        UPDATE ingredients
        SET inventory_stock = inventory_stock + NEW.quantity
        WHERE ingredient_id = NEW.ingredient_id;
    END IF;
END$$
DELIMITER ;

Note that this assumes that the delivery table has an ingredient_id column that is a foreign key referencing the ingredient_id column in the ingredients table. If this is not the case, you'll need to adjust the code accordingly.

To check if the same customer has placed the same order under different reservations, you need to modify the query in the $sql variable to include the reservation_id column in the WHERE clause.

Here's the modified code that includes both customer_id and reservation_id in the WHERE clause of the SQL query:

bash
$sql = "SELECT * FROM cart WHERE customer_id = ? AND reservation_id = ? OR (guest_id = ? AND customer_id IS NULL)";
$stmt = mysqli_prepare($conn, $sql);
mysqli_stmt_bind_param($stmt, "iii", $customer_id, $reservation_id, $guest_id);
mysqli_stmt_execute($stmt);
$result = mysqli_stmt_get_result($stmt);

This will retrieve all the orders that have the same customer_id and reservation_id as the current reservation.

Sure, you can modify the code to add a row at the bottom for the total quantity of the order. Here's how you can do it:

php
echo "<h2>Customer Summary</h2>";
echo "<form class='order-summary' action='customer_sum.php' method='POST'>";
echo "<table>";
echo "<tr><th>Dish Name</th><th>Quantity</th><th>Price</th><th>Total Price</th><th>Notes</th><th>Action</th></tr>";

$total_quantity = 0; // initialize total quantity to 0
$total_price = 0; // initialize total price to 0

while($row = $result->fetch_assoc()) {
    $cart_id = $row["cart_id"];
    $dish_id = $row["dish_id"];
    $quantity = $row["quantity"];
    $table_number = $row["table_number"];
    $reservation_id = $row["reservation_id"];
    $notes = $row["notes"];

    $sql = "SELECT dish_name, price FROM dishes WHERE dish_id = $dish_id";
    $dish_result = $conn->query($sql);
    $dish_row = $dish_result->fetch_assoc();
    $dish_name = $dish_row["dish_name"];
    $price = $dish_row["price"];
    $total_price_item = $price * $quantity;
    $total_quantity += $quantity; // add quantity to the total
    $total_price += $total_price_item; // add total price of the item to the total

    echo "<tr>";
    echo "<td>$dish_name</td>";
    echo "<td><input type='number' name='quantities[$cart_id]' value='$quantity'></td>";
    echo "<td> £ $price</td>";
    echo "<td>£ $total_price_item</td>";
    echo "<td><textarea class='expandable' name='notes[$cart_id]'>$notes</textarea></td>";
    echo "<td><button type='submit' name='delete' value='$cart_id'>Delete</button></td>";
    echo "</tr>";
}

// add a row at the bottom for total quantity and total price
echo "<tr>";
echo "<td><strong>Total Order</strong></td>";
echo "<td><strong>$total_quantity</strong></td>";
echo "<td></td>";
echo "<td><strong>£ $total_price</strong></td>";
echo "<td></td>";
echo "<td></td>";
echo "</tr>";

echo "</table>";
echo "<button type='submit' class='confirm-button' name='confirm_order'>Confirm Order</button>";
echo "</form>";
$conn->close();

This will display a new row at the bottom of the table with the total quantity of the order and the total price of the order, which is the sum of the total price of all items in the order.

Sure! To link the "Confirm Order" button to the form, you can wrap the entire form and the button in a <div> tag with an id attribute, like this:

css
echo "<div id='order-form'>";
echo "<form class='order-summary' action='customer_sum.php' method='POST'>";
// table code here
echo "<button type='submit' class='confirm-button' name='confirm_order'>Confirm Order</button>";
echo "</form>";
echo "</div>";

Then, you can add an onclick attribute to the "Confirm Order" button to trigger the form submission, like this:

css
echo "<button type='submit' class='confirm-button' name='confirm_order' onclick='document.getElementById(\"order-form\").submit()'>Confirm Order</button>";

This will submit the form when the "Confirm Order" button is clicked.

Yes, we can separate the PHP code to handle the update_order and confirm_order buttons separately. Here's an updated code that separates the logic:

php
if(isset($_POST['update_order'])) {
    updateCart();
} elseif(isset($_POST['confirm_order'])) {
    confirmOrder();
}

function updateCart() {
    global $conn;
    foreach($_POST['quantities'] as $cart_id => $quantity) {
        $notes = $_POST['notes'][$cart_id];
        $stmt = $conn->prepare("UPDATE cart SET quantity = ?, notes = ? WHERE cart_id = ?");
        $stmt->bind_param("isi", $quantity, $notes, $cart_id);
        $stmt->execute();
        $stmt->close();
    }
    header("Location: customer_sum.php");
    exit();
}

function confirmOrder() {
    global $conn;
    $unique_cart_ids = array();
    $customer_id = $_SESSION['customer_id'];
    $guest_id = $_SESSION['guest_id'];
    $reservation_id = $_SESSION['reservation_id'];
    $table_number = $_SESSION['table_number'];

    foreach ($_POST['quantities'] as $cart_id => $quantity) {
        $notes = $_POST['notes'][$cart_id];
        $stmt = $conn->prepare("UPDATE cart SET quantity = ?, notes = ?, status = 'confirmed' WHERE cart_id = ?");
        $stmt->bind_param("isi", $quantity, $notes, $cart_id);
        $stmt->execute();
        $stmt->close();

        $row = $conn->query("SELECT dish_id FROM cart WHERE cart_id = $cart_id")->fetch_assoc();
        $dish_id = $row['dish_id'];

        if (!in_array($cart_id, $unique_cart_ids)) {
            $stmt = $conn->prepare("INSERT IGNORE INTO orders (cart_id, reservation_id, customer_id, guest_id, table_number, dish_id, quantity, notes) 
            SELECT ?, ?, ?, ?, ?, d.dish_id, cart.quantity, cart.notes 
            FROM cart 
            JOIN dishes d ON cart.dish_id = d.dish_id 
            WHERE (customer_id = ? OR (guest_id = ? AND customer_id IS NULL))
              AND reservation_id = ? 
              AND table_number = ? 
              AND status = 'confirmed'
              AND cart.cart_id NOT IN (SELECT cart_id FROM orders)
        ");
        $stmt->bind_param("iiiiiiiii", $cart_id, $reservation_id, $customer_id, $guest_id, $table_number, $customer_id, $guest_id, $reservation_id, $table_number);

Based on the code provided, it seems that the if (isset($_POST['confirm_order'])) block is not being executed. This may be because the code to check for the confirm_order post variable is inside the foreach loop for updating the quantities and notes of the cart items.

To fix this, you can move the if (isset($_POST['confirm_order'])) block outside the foreach loop, so that it is not dependent on the updating of cart items. Here's an example of how you can do this:

php
if (isset($_POST['update_order'])) {
    $unique_cart_ids = array(); // array to keep track of unique cart IDs added to orders table
    foreach ($_POST['quantities'] as $cart_id => $quantity) {
        $notes = $_POST['notes'][$cart_id];
        $stmt = $conn->prepare("UPDATE cart SET quantity = ?, notes = ?, status = 'confirmed', cart_id = ? WHERE cart_id = ?");
        $stmt->bind_param("isii", $quantity, $notes, $cart_id, $cart_id);
        $stmt->execute();
        $stmt->close();
        
        // add cart ID to the array
        $unique_cart_ids[] = $cart_id;
    }
    
    // check for confirm_order post variable outside the foreach loop
    if (isset($_POST['confirm_order'])) {
        foreach ($unique_cart_ids as $cart_id) {
            $row = $conn->query("SELECT dish_id FROM cart WHERE cart_id = $cart_id")->fetch_assoc();
            $dish_id = $row['dish_id'];

            // check if cart ID is already in the array
            if (!in_array($cart_id, $unique_cart_ids)) {
                $stmt = $conn->prepare("INSERT IGNORE INTO orders (cart_id, reservation_id, customer_id, guest_id, table_number, dish_id, quantity, notes) 
                SELECT ?, ?, ?, ?, ?, d.dish_id, cart.quantity, cart.notes 
                FROM cart 
                JOIN dishes d ON cart.dish_id = d.dish_id 
                WHERE (customer_id = ? OR (guest_id = ? AND customer_id IS NULL))
                  AND reservation_id = ? 
                  AND table_number = ? 
                  AND status = 'confirmed'
                  AND cart.cart_id NOT IN (SELECT cart_id FROM orders)
            ");
            $stmt->bind_param("iiiiiiiii", $cart_id, $reservation_id, $customer_id, $guest_id, $table_number, $customer_id, $guest_id, $reservation_id, $table_number);

                $stmt->execute();
                $stmt->close();
                
                // add cart ID to the array
                $unique_cart_ids[] = $cart_id;
            }
            
            if ($reservation_id === null) {
                $row = $conn->query("SELECT reservation_id FROM cart WHERE cart_id = $cart_id")->fetch_assoc();
                $reservation_id = $row['reservation_id'];
            }
        }
        header("Location: customer_con_order.php");
        exit();
    }
    else {
        header("Location: customer_sum.php");
        exit();
    }
}

Note that in this example, the if (isset($_POST['confirm_order'])) block is executed only if the confirm_order post variable is set, and it loops through the unique cart IDs added to the array to insert them into the orders table. If the confirm_order post variable is not set, the code redirects the user to the summary page.

In the original code, the header("Location: customer_sum.php"); line is inside the foreach loop that updates the cart table. This means that it redirects the user to the summary page after each cart item is updated, which could result in the confirm_order button not being processed correctly.

In the modified code, the header("Location: customer_sum.php"); line has been moved outside the foreach loop and into an else block. This ensures that the page is only redirected to the summary page if the update_order button is pressed, and the confirm_order button is not pressed.

Additionally, the check for the uniqueness of the cart ID has been fixed. In the original code, the !in_array($cart_id, $unique_cart_ids) check was placed inside the if (!isset($_POST['confirm_order'])) block, which means that it was always true and the INSERT statement would never be executed. In the modified code, the check has been moved inside the foreach loop that loops through the unique_cart_ids array, which ensures that the INSERT statement is only executed for unique cart IDs.

To update the status when the Confirm Order button is pressed, you can modify the code to update the status of the cart in the foreach loop where you are inserting the order into the orders table. You can update the status of the cart to 'confirmed' before inserting the order into the orders table.

Here's the modified code:

php
if (isset($_POST['update_order'])) {
    $unique_cart_ids = array(); // array to keep track of unique cart IDs added to orders table
    foreach ($_POST['quantities'] as $cart_id => $quantity) {
        $notes = $_POST['notes'][$cart_id];
        $stmt = $conn->prepare("UPDATE cart SET quantity = ?, notes = ?, status = 'confirmed' WHERE cart_id = ?");
        $stmt->bind_param("isi", $quantity, $notes, $cart_id);
        $stmt->execute();
        $stmt->close();
        
        // add cart ID to the array
        $unique_cart_ids[] = $cart_id;
    }
    
    // check for confirm_order post variable outside the foreach loop
    if (isset($_POST['confirm_order'])) {
        foreach ($unique_cart_ids as $cart_id) {
            $row = $conn->query("SELECT dish_id FROM cart WHERE cart_id = $cart_id")->fetch_assoc();
            $dish_id = $row['dish_id'];

            $stmt = $conn->prepare("INSERT IGNORE INTO orders (cart_id, reservation_id, customer_id, guest_id, table_number, dish_id, quantity, notes) 
            SELECT ?, ?, ?, ?, ?, d.dish_id, cart.quantity, cart.notes 
            FROM cart 
            JOIN dishes d ON cart.dish_id = d.dish_id 
            WHERE (customer_id = ? OR (guest_id = ? AND customer_id IS NULL))
              AND reservation_id = ? 
              AND table_number = ? 
              AND status = 'confirmed'
              AND cart.cart_id NOT IN (SELECT cart_id FROM orders)
            ");
            $stmt->bind_param("iiiiiiiii", $cart_id, $reservation_id, $customer_id, $guest_id, $table_number, $customer_id, $guest_id, $reservation_id, $table_number);

            $stmt->execute();
            $stmt->close();

            if ($reservation_id === null) {
                $row = $conn->query("SELECT reservation_id FROM cart WHERE cart_id = $cart_id")->fetch_assoc();
                $reservation_id = $row['reservation_id'];
            }
        }
        header("Location: customer_con_order.php");
        exit();
    }
    else {
        header("Location: customer_sum.php");
        exit();
    }
}

In this modified code, the status of the cart is updated to 'confirmed' in the UPDATE query before the foreach loop for inserting orders is executed.

Sure, here's an updated version of the code that retrieves the reservation number from the orders table based on the guest or customer id stored in the session:

php
<?php
include_once 'C:\xampp\htdocs\RestaurantManagementSystem\lib\config.php';
include_once 'C:\xampp\htdocs\RestaurantManagementSystem\includes\header.php';

if (isset($_SESSION['customer_id'])) {
    $customer_id = $_SESSION['customer_id'];
    $guest_id = null;
} elseif (isset($_SESSION['guest_id'])) {
    $guest_id = $_SESSION['guest_id'];
    $customer_id = null;
} else {
    // handle case where no customer id is set in session
    $guest_id = null;
    $customer_id = null;
}

if ($guest_id !== null || $customer_id !== null) {
    $conn = mysqli_connect(DB_HOST, DB_USER, DB_PASSWORD, DB_NAME);
    if (!$conn) {
        die("Connection failed: " . mysqli_connect_error());
    }

    $id_column = $guest_id !== null ? 'guest_id' : 'customer_id';
    $id_value = $guest_id !== null ? $guest_id : $customer_id;

    $sql = "SELECT reservation_number FROM orders WHERE $id_column = $id_value";
    $result = mysqli_query($conn, $sql);
    if (mysqli_num_rows($result) > 0) {
        $row = mysqli_fetch_assoc($result);
        $reservation_id = $row['reservation_number'];
    } else {
        $reservation_id = null;
    }

    mysqli_close($conn);
} else {
    $reservation_id = null;
}

?>
<html>
<header>
  <link rel="stylesheet" href="\RestaurantManagementSystem\assets\css\employer_style.css">
  <link rel="stylesheet" href="\RestaurantManagementSystem\assets\css\header_style.css">
  <h1>Menu</h1>
</header>
<body>
	<h1>Thank You for Your Order!</h1>
	<p>Reservation ID: <?php echo $reservation_id ?? $_SESSION['reservation_id']; ?></p>
	<h2>Order Summary:</h2>
	<table>
		<tr>
			<th>Item</th>
			<th>Quantity</th>
			<th>Price</th>
		</tr>
		<?php
		foreach ($_SESSION['order_items'] as $item) {
			echo "<tr><td>{$item['name']}</td><td>{$item['quantity']}</td><td>{$item['price']}</td></tr>";
		}
		?>
		<tr>
			<th colspan="2">Total:</th>
			<td><?php echo $_SESSION['order_total']; ?></td>
		</tr>
	</table>
	<a href="index.php">Return to Home</a>
	<a href="receipt.php">View Receipt</a>
</body>
</html>

In this updated version, I've added a new block of code that retrieves the reservation number from the orders table based on the guest or customer id stored in the session. If a guest or customer id is found in the session, the code connects to the database and runs a query to retrieve the reservation number for the corresponding id. The reservation number is then stored in the $reservation_id variable.

In the <p> tag that displays the reservation ID, I've added a check to see if the $reservation_id variable is set. If it is, then that value is displayed, otherwise, the reservation ID stored in the session is displayed as before.

Certainly, here is an example of how you can create an HTML table and use PHP to retrieve the order details and calculate the total:

php
<?php
include_once 'C:\xampp\htdocs\RestaurantManagementSystem\lib\config.php';
include_once 'C:\xampp\htdocs\RestaurantManagementSystem\includes\header.php';

if (isset($_SESSION['customer_id'])) {
    $customer_id = $_SESSION['customer_id'];
    $guest_id = null;
} elseif (isset($_SESSION['guest_id'])) {
    $guest_id = $_SESSION['guest_id'];
    $customer_id = null;
} else {
    // handle case where no customer id is set in session
    $guest_id = null;
    $customer_id = null;
}

if ($guest_id !== null || $customer_id !== null) {
    $conn = mysqli_connect(DB_HOST, DB_USER, DB_PASSWORD, DB_NAME);
    if (!$conn) {
        die("Connection failed: " . mysqli_connect_error());
    }

    $id_column = $guest_id !== null ? 'guest_id' : 'customer_id';
    $id_value = $guest_id !== null ? $guest_id : $customer_id;

    $sql = "SELECT dish_id, quantity FROM orders WHERE $id_column = $id_value";
    $result = mysqli_query($conn, $sql);
    if (mysqli_num_rows($result) > 0) {
        $orders = mysqli_fetch_all($result, MYSQLI_ASSOC);
    } else {
        $orders = null;
    }

    mysqli_close($conn);
} else {
    $orders = null;
}

$total = 0;
?>

<html>
<header>
    <link rel="stylesheet" href="\RestaurantManagementSystem\assets\css\employer_style.css">
    <link rel="stylesheet" href="\RestaurantManagementSystem\assets\css\header_style.css">
    <h1>Menu</h1>
</header>
<body>
    <h1>Thank You for Your Order!</h1>
    <?php if ($orders !== null): ?>
        <h2>Order Summary:</h2>
        <table>
            <thead>
                <tr>
                    <th>Dish ID</th>
                    <th>Quantity</th>
                    <th>Price</th>
                </tr>
            </thead>
            <tbody>
                <?php foreach ($orders as $order): ?>
                    <?php
                        $dish_id = $order['dish_id'];
                        $quantity = $order['quantity'];
                        $price = getDishPrice($dish_id);
                        $subtotal = $price * $quantity;
                        $total += $subtotal;
                    ?>
                    <tr>
                        <td><?php echo $dish_id; ?></td>
                        <td><?php echo $quantity; ?></td>
                        <td>$<?php echo number_format($price, 2); ?></td>
                    </tr>
                <?php endforeach; ?>
                <tr>
                    <td></td>
                    <td><strong>Total:</strong></td>
                    <td>$<?php echo number_format($total, 2); ?></td>
                </tr>
            </tbody>
        </table>
    <?php else: ?>
        <p>No orders found.</p>
    <?php endif; ?>
    <form action="index.php" method="get">
        <button type="submit">Return to Home</button>
    </form>
    <form action="receipt.php" method="get">
        <input type="hidden" name="reservation_id" value="<?php echo $reservation_id; ?>">
        <button type="submit">View Receipt</button>
    </form>
</body>
</html>

To retrieve the dish IDs and quantities for the orders associated with the reservation ID and customer or guest ID, you can modify the code as follows:

php
<?php
include_once 'C:\xampp\htdocs\RestaurantManagementSystem\lib\config.php';
include_once 'C:\xampp\htdocs\RestaurantManagementSystem\includes\header.php';

if (isset($_SESSION['customer_id'])) {
    $customer_id = $_SESSION['customer_id'];
    $guest_id = null;
} elseif (isset($_SESSION['guest_id'])) {
    $guest_id = $_SESSION['guest_id'];
    $customer_id = null;
} else {
    // handle case where no customer id is set in session
    $guest_id = null;
    $customer_id = null;
}

if ($guest_id !== null || $customer_id !== null) {

    $id_column = $guest_id !== null ? 'guest_id' : 'customer_id';
    $id_value = $guest_id !== null ? $guest_id : $customer_id;

    $sql = "SELECT reservation_id FROM orders WHERE $id_column = $id_value";
    $result = mysqli_query($conn, $sql);
    if (mysqli_num_rows($result) > 0) {
        $row = mysqli_fetch_assoc($result);
        $reservation_id = $row['reservation_id'];
        
        $sql = "SELECT dish_id, quantity FROM order_items WHERE reservation_id = $reservation_id";
        $result = mysqli_query($conn, $sql);
        if (mysqli_num_rows($result) > 0) {
            echo "<table>";
            echo "<tr><th>Dish ID</th><th>Quantity</th></tr>";
            while ($row = mysqli_fetch_assoc($result)) {
                echo "<tr><td>" . $row['dish_id'] . "</td><td>" . $row['quantity'] . "</td></tr>";
            }
            echo "</table>";
        } else {
            echo "No orders found for reservation ID $reservation_id and $id_column $id_value.";
        }
    } else {
        $reservation_id = null;
    }

    mysqli_close($conn);
} else {
    $reservation_id = null;
}

?>
<html>
<header>
  <link rel="stylesheet" href="\RestaurantManagementSystem\assets\css\employer_style.css">
  <link rel="stylesheet" href="\RestaurantManagementSystem\assets\css\header_style.css">
  <h1>Menu</h1>
</header>
<body>
	<h1>Thank You for Your Order!</h1>
	<p>Reservation ID: <?php echo $reservation_id; ?></p>
		<h2>Order Summary:</h2>
	<?php
	if ($reservation_id !== null) {
	    echo '<a href="receipt.php">View Receipt</a>';
	}
	?>
	<a href="index.php">Return to Home</a>
</body>
</html>

The code above first checks whether the customer ID or guest ID is set in the session, and then queries the orders table to retrieve the reservation ID associated with the ID value. If a reservation ID is found, the code then queries the order_items table to retrieve the dish IDs and quantities for the orders associated with the reservation ID. The code then outputs the dish IDs and quantities in an HTML table.

Note that the code above assumes that the order_items table has columns named reservation_id, dish_id, and quantity. You may need to modify the code if your database schema is different. Also, the code above only outputs the HTML for the order summary table if there are orders associated with the reservation ID and customer or guest ID. If there are no

The code seems to be correctly putting the reservation_id, table_number, full_name, and name values in hidden form fields. However, it is using the method="get" attribute on the form, which means that these values will be sent as URL parameters, not as part of the request body. This means that the values will not be visible in the URL unless they are explicitly added to the form's action attribute.

To make the values visible in the URL, you can modify the form's action attribute to include the parameters. For example:

php
echo '<form method="get" action="customer_menu.php?';
echo 'reservation_id='.$row["reservation_id"].'&';
echo 'table_number='.$row["table_number"].'&';
if (!empty($row["full_name"])) {
    echo 'full_name='.$row["full_name"].'&';
} elseif (!empty($row["name"])) {
    echo 'name='.$row["name"].'&';
}
echo '">
    <input type="submit" value="Return to Home">
</form>';

Similarly, for the receipt form, you can modify the action attribute to include the parameters:

php
echo '<form method="get" action="..\employers\customerReceipts.php?';
echo 'reservation_id='.$row["reservation_id"].'&';
echo 'table_number='.$row["table_number"].'&';
if (!empty($row["full_name"])) {
    echo 'full_name='.$row["full_name"].'&';
} elseif (!empty($row["name"])) {
    echo 'name='.$row["name"].'&';
}
echo '">
    <input style="margin-top: -100px;" type="submit" value="View Receipt">
</form>';

It seems that the code is not putting the reservation_id, table_number, full_name, or name in the URL because the form method used to send the data to the URL is GET, and the variables are not being properly set in the URL. The form action used in the HTML code is "customer_menu.php", which means that the variables are being sent to this file when the form is submitted. However, the variables are not being properly set in the URL because the input type used is "hidden", which means that the values of the variables are not visible to the user.

To fix this issue, you can change the input type to "text" and set the value of the input field to the variable you want to pass in the URL. For example, you can replace the following lines of code:

python
<input type="hidden" name="reservation_id" value="'.$row["reservation_id"].'">
<input type="hidden" name="table_number" value="'.$row["table_number"].'">
<input type="hidden" name="customer_id" value="'.$row["full_name"].'">
<input type="hidden" name="guest_id" value="'.$row["name"].'">

with:

php
<input type="text" name="reservation_id" value="<?php echo $row['reservation_id']; ?>">
<input type="text" name="table_number" value="<?php echo $row['table_number']; ?>">
<input type="text" name="full_name" value="<?php echo $row['full_name']; ?>">
<input type="text" name="name" value="<?php echo $row['name']; ?>">

This will make the values of the variables visible in the URL when the form is submitted.

html
<form method="post" action="process.php">
  <input type="text" name="username" placeholder="Username">
  <input type="password" name="password" placeholder="Password">
  <button type="submit">Submit</button>
  <button type="reset">Reset</button>
</form>

In this example, the two buttons are used to submit or reset the form, respectively. Note that the first button has a type of "submit", which makes it submit the form to the server. The second button has a type of "reset", which resets the form fields to their initial values.

This is a PHP code that retrieves the reservation_id from the orders table based on the customer_id or guest_id stored in the session. The reservation_id is then displayed in the HTML code. Additionally, if the reservation_id, table_number, and either full_name or name are available, two forms are displayed - one to return to the homepage and one to view the receipt.

To set the values in the URL, you can use the session variables guest_id or customer_id. For example, to set the guest_id in the URL, you can add the following code to the form that returns to the homepage:

php
<input type="hidden" name="guest_id" value="<?php echo $guest_id; ?>">

And to set the customer_id in the URL, you can add the following code:

php
<input type="hidden" name="customer_id" value="<?php echo $customer_id; ?>">

Note that these should be added to the same form that already contains the reservation_id and table_number inputs.

Certainly, here is an example PHP code that retrieves the table_number and reservation_id from the orders table and stores them in variables for later use in a URL:

php
<?php
include_once 'C:\xampp\htdocs\RestaurantManagementSystem\lib\config.php';
include_once 'C:\xampp\htdocs\RestaurantManagementSystem\includes\header.php';

if (isset($_SESSION['customer_id'])) {
    $customer_id = $_SESSION['customer_id'];
    $guest_id = null;
} elseif (isset($_SESSION['guest_id'])) {
    $guest_id = $_SESSION['guest_id'];
    $customer_id = null;
} else {
    // handle case where no customer id is set in session
    $guest_id = null;
    $customer_id = null;
}

if ($guest_id !== null || $customer_id !== null) {

    $id_column = $guest_id !== null ? 'guest_id' : 'customer_id';
    $id_value = $guest_id !== null ? $guest_id : $customer_id;

    $sql = "SELECT table_number, reservation_id FROM orders WHERE $id_column = $id_value";
    $result = mysqli_query($conn, $sql);
    if (mysqli_num_rows($result) > 0) {
        $row = mysqli_fetch_assoc($result);
        $table_number = $row['table_number'];
        $reservation_id = $row['reservation_id'];
    } else {
        $table_number = null;
        $reservation_id = null;
    }

    mysqli_close($conn);
} else {
    $table_number = null;
    $reservation_id = null;
}
?>

After executing this code, the variables $table_number and $reservation_id will contain the corresponding values from the orders table. You can then use these variables in a URL like this:

php
<a href="somepage.php?table_number=<?php echo $table_number ?>&reservation_id=<?php echo $reservation_id ?>">Link</a>

Replace somepage.php with the URL of the page you want to link to.

There are many possible options for a client-side menu UI for a restaurant employer. Here are a few ideas:

  1. Simple list: You can create a simple list of items with their names, descriptions, and prices. This can be displayed in a single column or multiple columns, depending on the number of items.

  2. Grid view: You can display the menu items in a grid with images, names, descriptions, and prices. This can make it easier for the employer to browse the menu and find what they're looking for.

  3. Categories: You can organize the menu items into categories, such as appetizers, entrees, and desserts. This can make it easier for the employer to find items within a particular category.

  4. Search bar: You can include a search bar that allows the employer to search for specific items on the menu.

  5. Filters: You can include filters that allow the employer to narrow down the menu items based on criteria such as price range, dietary restrictions, or availability.

  6. Interactive menu: You can create an interactive menu that allows the employer to click on items to see more information, add them to their order, or customize them in some way.

  7. Mobile-friendly design: Make sure the UI is mobile-friendly since the employer may be using a phone or tablet to browse the menu.

  8. Easy navigation: Make sure the menu is easy to navigate and items are easy to find, so the employer doesn't get frustrated and gives up.

  9. Accessibility: Make sure the menu is accessible to people with disabilities, such as those who are visually impaired or have mobility issues.

Overall, the most important thing is to create a user-friendly and visually appealing UI that makes it easy for the employer to browse and order from the menu.

Sure, here's an example code for a book a table page with a calendar and a table that shows 10 tables and their availability:

php
<?php
  // Initialize variables
  $date = date('Y-m-d');
  $tables = array();
  
  // Check if a date is selected
  if(isset($_POST['date'])) {
    $date = $_POST['date'];
  }
  
  // Check reservations for the selected date
  $reservations = array(
    '2022-05-01' => array(2, 3),
    '2022-05-02' => array(1, 5, 6),
    '2022-05-03' => array(4),
    // add more reservations here
  );
  
  // Generate table availability array
  for($i = 1; $i <= 10; $i++) {
    if(in_array($i, $reservations[$date] ?? [])) {
      $tables[$i] = 'Not Available';
    } else {
      $tables[$i] = 'Available';
    }
  }
?>

<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
<head>
  <title>Book a Table</title>
  <link rel="stylesheet" href="https://maxcdn.bootstrapcdn.com/bootstrap/3.3.7/css/bootstrap.min.css">
  <script src="https://ajax.googleapis.com/ajax/libs/jquery/3.3.1/jquery.min.js"></script>
  <script src="https://maxcdn.bootstrapcdn.com/bootstrap/3.3.7/js/bootstrap.min.js"></script>
  <style>
    .calendar {
      width: 30%;
      float: left;
    }
    .table-availability {
      width: 60%;
      float: left;
    }
  </style>
</head>
<body>

<div class="container">
  <h2>Book a Table</h2>
  
  <div class="calendar">
    <form method="POST" action="">
      <div class="form-group">
        <label for="date">Select a date:</label>
        <input type="date" class="form-control" id="date" name="date" value="<?php echo $date; ?>">
      </div>
      <button type="submit" class="btn btn-default">Check Availability</button>
    </form>
  </div>
  
  <div class="table-availability">
    <h4>Table Availability for <?php echo $date; ?>:</h4>
    <table class="table table-bordered">
      <thead>
        <tr>
          <th>Table Number</th>
          <th>Availability</th>
        </tr>
      </thead>
      <tbody>
        <?php foreach($tables as $tableNumber => $availability) { ?>
          <tr>
            <td><?php echo $tableNumber; ?></td>
            <td><?php echo $availability; ?></td>
          </tr>
        <?php } ?>
      </tbody>
    </table>
  </div>
  
</div>

</body>
</html>

This code uses Bootstrap CSS and JavaScript to style the page and create a responsive layout. It includes a form with a calendar input to select a date, and a table to display the availability of 10 tables for the selected date. The availability data is generated based on an example reservations array, but you can modify it to match your database structure and queries.

1 / 1

Here's an example code that generates time slots of 1 hour each between the opening and closing times for each day of the week:

php
<?php
// Define opening and closing times
$openingTimes = array(
    "Monday" => "12:00",
    "Tuesday" => "12:00",
    "Wednesday" => "12:00",
    "Thursday" => "12:00",
    "Friday" => "12:00",
    "Saturday" => "11:00",
    "Sunday" => "11:00"
);
$closingTimes = array(
    "Monday" => "22:00",
    "Tuesday" => "22:00",
    "Wednesday" => "22:00",
    "Thursday" => "22:00",
    "Friday" => "22:00",
    "Saturday" => "23:00",
    "Sunday" => "23:00"
);

// Generate time slots for each day of the week
$timeSlots = array();
foreach ($openingTimes as $day => $openingTime) {
    $closingTime = $closingTimes[$day];
    $currentTime = strtotime($openingTime);
    while ($currentTime <= strtotime($closingTime)) {
        $timeSlots[$day][] = date("h:i A", $currentTime);
        $currentTime = strtotime("+1 hour", $currentTime);
    }
}

// Print time slots for each day of the week
foreach ($timeSlots as $day => $slots) {
    echo "<h3>$day</h3>";
    foreach ($slots as $slot) {
        echo "<p>$slot</p>";
    }
}
?>

You can modify this code to include a calendar for selecting the reservation date and display the available time slots for the selected date.

To combine the time slots with the table availability in the HTML, you can add a new column to the table for the time slots and include a dropdown menu for the user to select a time slot when making a reservation. Here's an example of how you can modify the table-availability section of the code:

php
<div class="table-availability">
  <h4>Table Availability for <?php echo $date; ?>:</h4>
  <table class="table table-bordered">
    <thead>
      <tr>
        <th>Table Number</th>
        <th>Availability</th>
        <th>Time Slot</th>
      </tr>
    </thead>
    <tbody>
      <?php foreach($tables as $tableNumber => $availability) { ?>
        <tr>
          <td><?php echo $tableNumber; ?></td>
          <td><?php echo $availability; ?></td>
          <td>
            <?php if($availability == 'Available') { ?>
              <select name="time_slot_<?php echo $tableNumber; ?>">
                <?php foreach($timeSlots[date('l', strtotime($date))] as $slot) { ?>
                  <option value="<?php echo $slot; ?>"><?php echo $slot; ?></option>
                <?php } ?>
              </select>
            <?php } else { ?>
              Not Available
            <?php } ?>
          </td>
        </tr>
      <?php } ?>
    </tbody>
  </table>
</div>

This code adds a new column for the time slot and checks if the table is available. If the table is available, it adds a dropdown menu with the time slots for the selected date. If the table is not available, it displays "Not Available" in the time slot column. The name of the dropdown menu includes the table number so that the selected time slot can be submitted along with the reservation.

php

    echo "<p>$slot</p>";
}

$tables = array();

  $date = $_POST['date'];
}

// Fetch reservations for the selected date
$reservations_query = "SELECT table_number FROM reservations WHERE date = '$date'";
$reservations_result = mysqli_query($connection, $reservations_query);
$reservations = array();
while($row = mysqli_fetch_assoc($reservations_result)) {
  $reservations[] = $row['table_number'];
}

// Fetch table numbers and availability
$tables_query = "SELECT table_number, available FROM tables";
$tables_result = mysqli_query($connection, $tables_query);
while($row = mysqli_fetch_assoc($tables_result)) {
  $table_number = $row['table_number'];
  $availability = $row['available'];
  if(in_array($table_number, $reservations)) {
    $tables[$table_number] = 'Not Available';
  } else if($availability) {
    $tables[$table_number] = 'Available';
  } else {
    $tables[$table_number] = 'Not Available';
  }
}
